case_name: Civil Appeal Nos. 1711 to 1721, 7123, 1699, 1706, 1744 of 1974 and connected matters

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1711 to 1721, 7123, 1699, 1706, 1744 of 1974 from Judgment and Order dated 24th April 1974 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 391 etc. of 1970

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 1711 to 1721, 7123, 1699, 1706 1744 of 1974. From the Judgment and Order dated the 24th April, 1974 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 391, 392, 395, 394, 412, 401, 405, 430, 400, 399, 403, 390, 409, 417 and 407 of 1970 respectively.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1267 of 1970 from judgment and Order dated 8th April 1970 of Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 995 of 1970

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1267 of 1970. From the judgment and Order dated the 8th April, 1970 of the, Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 995 of 1970.

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 436 of 1971, 26 and 133 of 1972 under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petitions Nos. 436 of 1971 and 26 and 133 of 1972. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Prior to 1 April 1964 licences for sale of foreign liquor in Madhya Pradesh granted under fee per bottle system

anchor.surface_text: Prior to 1 April, 1964 licences for sale of foreign liquor in Madhya Pradesh were granted by the excise authorities under the fee per bottle system.

facts.text: In 1964-65 State of Madhya Pradesh decided licences for foreign liquor disposed by public auction to highest bidder

anchor.surface_text: In 1964-65 the State decided that licences for foreign liquor would be disposed of by public auction to the highest bidder.

facts.text: Appellants challenged authority of State Government to hold public auction for foreign liquor licences in Madhya Pradesh High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then challenged in the Madhya Pradesh High Court the authority, of the State Government to hold public auction for grant of licences for foreign liquor.

facts.text: Appellants did not succeed in challenge because Act amended in 1964 empowering grant of lease for any liquor

anchor.surface_text: The appellants did number succeed because the Act was amended in 1964. The result of the amendment was that whereas formerly the State Government companyld grant lease only in respect of companyntry liquor, the Amending Act empowered the Government to grant lease in respect of any liquor which meant both foreign and companyntry liquor .

facts.text: Public auctions held under section 18 of Madhya Pradesh Act for foreign liquor after amendment

anchor.surface_text: After the amendment, public auctions were held under section 18 of the Madhya Pradesh Act in respect of foreign liquor is well.

facts.text: In 1965-66 public auctions held for foreign liquor leases renewed up to 1969-70

anchor.surface_text: In 1956-66 public auctions were held in respect of foreign liquor. The leases were renewed up to 1969-70.

facts.text: In 1967-68 prohibition withdrawn in certain areas of Madhya Pradesh and new foreign liquor vends opened disposed by public auction

anchor.surface_text: In 1967-68 prohibition was withdrawn in certain areas of Madhya Pradesh And new foreign liquor vends were opened. These vends were disposed of by public auction.

facts.text: Notification dated 29 March 1968 by State Government ordered with effect from 1 April 1965 foreign liquor licences disposed on extra fee of Rs. 1000 plus fee per bottle

anchor.surface_text: In 1968 the State Government by a numberification dated 29 March, 1968 ordered that with effect from 1 April, 1965 foreign liquor licence shall be disposed of on payment of extra fee of Rs. 1000 in addition to the payment of a fee per bottle at specified rates.

facts.text: Notification dated 14 August 1970 State Government to dispose foreign liquor licences by public auction subject of Madhya Pradesh appeals

anchor.surface_text: In 1970 there was a numberification dated 14 August, 1970 where the State Government would dispose of foreign liquor licences by public auction. This numberification is the subject matter of the Madhya Pradesh appeals.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh appeals governed by Central Provinces and Berar Excise Act 1915

anchor.surface_text: The Madhya Pradesh appeals are governed by the Central Pro- vinces and Berar Excise Act 1915 which became applicable to Madhya Pradesh as the Central Provinces Excise Act, 1915.

facts.text: Kerala appeals governed by Abkari Act No. 1

anchor.surface_text: The Kerala Appeals are governed by the Abkari Act  Act No. 1 This will be referred to as the Abkari Act.

facts.text: Appellants contend fundamental right to carry on trade in liquor not declared monopoly of State

anchor.surface_text: The companytention on behalf of the appellants is that it is the fundamental right of the citizens to carry on trade in liquor. It is said that the right to trade in liquor is number declared by the legislature to be a monopoly of the State

facts.text: State contends auction of licences is consideration for lease under section 18 MP Act or 18A Abkari Act

anchor.surface_text: The State companytends that the highest bid represents the companysideration for the lease under section 18 of the Madhya Pradesh Act or section 18A of the Abkari Act.

facts.text: State has power under sections 8 and 9 MP Act to prohibit import export transport of intoxicants

anchor.surface_text: The Madhya Pradesh Act by sections 8 and 9 companyfers power on the State to prohibit import, export or transport of any intoxicant.

facts.text: Section 18 MP Act allows State to lease right of selling liquor by retail within specified area

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 states that the State Government may lease to any person on such companyditions and for such period as it may think fit the right  a  of manufacturing or of supplying by wholesale, or of both, or  b  of selling by wholesale or by retail,

facts.text: Section 18A Abkari Act allows Government to grant privilege of selling liquor by retail on payment of rental settled by auction

anchor.surface_text: Section 18A of the Abkari Act companyfers power on the Government to grant, on such companyditions and for such period as the Government may deem fit the exclusive or other privilege  i  of manufacturing or supplying by whole- sale or  ii  of selling by retail

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the civil appeals and writ petitions

anchor.surface_text: The appeals and the writ petitions are, therefore, dismissed. Parties will pay and bear their own companyts.

issues.text: whether it is permissible for the State Government to auction licences for carrying on the business of selling foreign liquor which is neither manufactured nor imported by the State Government

anchor.surface_text: The principal question in these civil appeals and writ petitions is whether it is permissible for the State Government to auction licences for carrying on the business of selling foreign liquor which is neither manufactured nor imported by the State Government.

issues.text: whether citizens have a fundamental right under Article 19(1)(g) to carry on trade or business in intoxicating liquor

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the right to trade in liquor is not declared by the legislature to be a monopoly of the State to exclude trade in liquor from the operation of Article 19 1 g  as a fundamental right to trade.

issues.text: whether the State has the exclusive right or privilege of manufacturing and selling liquor, which it can grant by licence or lease via public auction

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the State has the exclusive right or privilege of manufacturing and selling liquor. The State grants such right or privilege in the shape of a licence or a lease.

holdings.text: The State has the exclusive right or privilege of manufacturing and selling liquor. The State grants such right or privilege in the shape of a licence or a lease.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the State has the exclusive right or privilege of manufacturing and selling liquor. The State grants such right or privilege in the shape of a licence or a lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court relies on police power, Article 47 directive for prohibition, historical excise regulations showing state monopoly, and precedents like Bharucha confirming no citizen right and auction as regulation.

holdings.text: The State has the power to hold a public auction for grant of such right or privilege and accept payment of a sum in consideration of grant of lease.

anchor.surface_text: The State has the power to hold a public auction for grant of such right or privilege and accept payment of a sum in consideration of grant of lease. The appeals and the writ petitions are, therefore, dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying sections 18 MP Act and 18A Abkari Act authorizing lease by auction, Entry 8 List II, and precedents upholding auctions for liquor privileges as regulatory revenue measure.

holdings.text: there is no fundamental right of citizens to carry on trade or to do business in liquor

anchor.surface_text: There are three principal reasons to hold that there is no fundamental right of citizens to carry on trade or to do business in liquor. First, there is the police power of the State to enforce public morality to prohibit trades in noxious or dangerous goods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three reasons: police power for morality, Article 47 for prohibition, historical state monopoly; follows Bharucha rejecting inherent right, distinguishes Narula as not overruling it.

holdings.text: The amount of bid at a public auction represents the consideration for the grant of such right or privilege

anchor.surface_text: The Government can hold a public auction to grant lease. The State Government accepts payment of a sum in consideration of the grant of any lease. The amount of bid at a public auction represents the consideration for the grant of such right or privilege.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bid is rental/consideration for lease of privilege under s18 MP Act/s18A Abkari Act, not tax/fee; affirmed by historical practice and precedents like Guruswamy, Abdulkadir.

holdings.text: Rental is neither a tax nor an excise duty. Rental is the consideration for the agreement for grant of privilege by the Government.

anchor.surface_text: Rental is the consideration for the privilege granted by the Government for manufacturing or vending liquor. Rental is neither a tax nor an excise duty. Rental is the consideration for the agreement for grant of privilege by the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes rental as contractual consideration for privilege lease from tax/duty, consistent with auction system in excise laws and precedents.
